{{Infobox Museum |name= Civil War Museum of Philadelphia |image= |caption= |imagesize= |latitude= |longitude= |established= 1888 |location= |type= |visitors= |director= |curator= |website= http://civilwarmuseumphila.org }} The '''Civil War Museum of Philadelphia''' (formerly the Civil War and Underground Railroad Museum of Philadelphia and previously the Civil War Library and Museum) in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], claims to be the oldest chartered [[American Civil War]] institution in the United States. The museum was founded in 1888 by veteran officers of the [[Union Army]], Navy and Marine Corps.
As of March 2016, the museum is closed to the public. While closed, its collection is being stored at the [[Gettysburg Museum and Visitor Center]], where an exhibition of material from the collection was planned for 2013. Artifacts are also on exhibit at the [[National Museum of American Jewish History]] in Philadelphia and the [[African American Museum in Philadelphia]].<ref name=Collection>{{cite web|url=http://civilwarmuseumphila.org/collection |title=Civil War Museum of Philadelphia; The Museum's Collection |publisher=Civilwarmuseumphila.org |date= |accessdate=2014-02-25}}</ref>
==Location== On August 7, 2007, the museum announced that it would relocate from 1805 Pine Street near [[Rittenhouse Square]] to the former [[First Bank of the United States]] building, near [[Independence Hall (United States)|Independence Hall]]. Philadelphia Mayor [[John F. Street]] presented the museum with a check for $1.2 million to assist in its relocation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20165392/ |title=Oldest Civil War museum gets a new home |publisher= MSNBC.com |date=August 7, 2007}}</ref> On August 2, 2008, the Pine Street location permanently closed and the museum planned to reopen in its new location in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/20080801_Phila__Civil_War_museum_holds_open_house_before_closing.html |title=Phila. Civil War museum holds open house before closing |publisher= ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' |date=August 1, 2008}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cwurmuseum.org/index.htm] {{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
In 2009, [[Governor of Pennsylvania|Governor]] [[Ed Rendell]] canceled the state's portion of the funding needed to relocate the museum, prompting the [[National Park Service]] to withdraw its offer to use the First Bank building.<ref>[http://www.philly.com/inquirer/opinion/20090724_Editorial__History_without_a_home.html "Editorial: History without a home"], ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', July 24, 2009</ref>
The museum announced plans to reopen in a new, unspecified location in 2014<ref name=Collection/> or 2015.<ref name=Colimore>{{cite news |last=Colimore |first=Edward |date=8 March 2010 |title=Old Baldy to return to Frankford Civil War museum |url=http://articles.philly.com/2010-03-08/news/24957443_1_civil-war-museum-american-jewish-history-african-american-museum |newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer |location=Philadelphia, PA |access-date=16 March 2016 }}</ref> However, the plans did not materialize and no updates have been announced as of March 2016.
==Collection== The museum displayed the mounted head of "[[Old Baldy (horse)|Old Baldy]]", the horse that was ridden by Union [[Major General]] [[George G. Meade]] during most of the Civil War. Old Baldy's head was mounted in 1882 and restored in 1991. In 2010, it was returned to its owner, the [[Grand Army of the Republic Museum and Library]] in Philadelphia, which had loaned it to the Civil War Museum over 30 years before.<ref name=Colimore/>
In addition to a large portrait and artifacts associated with General Meade, the museum's has personal items from other Union generals including [[Ulysses S. Grant]], [[John F. Reynolds]], and [[George B. McClellan]].
The collection also includes a large number of military [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheons]], which were made in the United States from the end of the Civil War until about 1907. They resemble a [[coat of arms]] and depict the military record of a veteran. Usually commissioned by the veteran or his family to memorialize his service, they were produced by an artist using [[chromolithography]].
The museum has items pertaining to [[Abraham Lincoln]], including a cast of his hands, a [[lock of hair]], and a [[death mask]].
